title: Being Toxic[to the enemy team] (might) increases winrate
body:
I did this experiment to test out whether being toxic would increase my winrate.
Played a 200 games
100 chat is muted
100 im flaming like an orangutan
when chat is muted I win 48
when I'm being toxic to the enemy team I win 54
I know I should probably have more matches and look at matches that were win/lost in lobby and such but I still doubt that would affect the 6% wr increase.
This is sad
TL;DR = If you want to climb be toxic to the enemy team, or you could be a good person and lose.
P.S. {{champion:157}}  mains also seem to be the most toxic players with 46% of them being toxic in games I encountered during this study.

replies.body:
Apart from the effect being too small given the sample size, there's the additional problem that your previous experiment has a result on the next. After all your MMR changes while you play. I guess the best approach would be deciding at random whether to mute or flame, as this removes any bias created through the order of experiments over time.
This would also fix the issue of winrate itself not being interesting in the long run, as either approach should eventually yield 50% winrate. By randomizing the approach per game you should get a 50% winrate, which is the result of your average performance using both strategies, meaning you would have a way of directly comparing your performance with each method.

Only one problem left, easily highlighted in that last sentence: **your** performance.
The biggest problem with the sample size of your "study" isn't the number of games, it's the number of players: One. And a sample size of one doesn't really allow you to make any conclusions about a larger group.

This does make me wonder though- if Riot quietly muted opposing players in random games, then likewise inserted trigger-activated flaming chatbots while still muting opposing players, and logged the results with a spread based on the expected performance.

I bet it _would_ impact games.

>I bet it would impact games.

the problem is that you're betting the outcome based on your own expectations of what will/should happen
Really, I'm sure of it- otherwise, all this chat banning would be inane. It would be good to have numbers to back it up. There should be expected results in any experiment.

This is actually a very small sample size, and one that it's not really reasonable to draw conclusions from. Both 48 and 54 are well within the margin of error for an approximately 50% win rate over a number of games, and 100 is far too small a total number to draw conclusions from as a result.

Additionally, many things that are against the rules increase your win rate. I am more likely to win a game of soccer if, at the start of the game, I shoot the other team's goalie in the leg. That doesn't mean it's okay to do, or that I should do it.

The thing is there's not enough evidence here to really even count as a study. I recently had leavers in two promo series in a row, but that doesn't mean that promos are any more likely to have leavers in them, and to call it evidence that might be the case would be actively misleading, because the data set is simply not sufficient to even start drawing that sort of conclusion.

All you have really established here is that, in the course of a hundred games, you came within the approximately expected win rate both times. Anything else is probably a statistically unfair assertion to make or even suggest, and is a misapplication of statistical analysis at best, especially as we don't have any indication of what champions or roles you played, how often you played, or at what times you played. These and more are all factors that can severely influence your win rate, which is why this is effectively a misleading statement to make even as a suggestion.

None the less, I think you are correct in concept, but I hope you are exaggerating with "flaming like an orangutan". We don't need or want that.
